newsitem.title: UK: Oil bounces but no end to price slide yet in sight.
newsitem.headline: Oil bounces but no end to price slide yet in sight.

text.p: Oil prices bounced on Tuesday but the move was seen unlikely to herald more than a temporary pause to a slide that has seen levels slump by more than 20 percent in just six weeks.
"It is a bounce from an oversold situation," said Peter Gignoux, manager of Smith Barney's petroleum desk in London, adding that the weather, particularly for the U.S. market, remains the key.
International benchmark Brent Blend futures for April delivery on London's International Petroleum Exchange (IPE) was 46 cents higher at $19.58 per barrel at 1636 GMT.
Brent hit a low of $19.09 on Monday and is still almost $5 below the high seen in January.
A mild winter in the northern hemisphere and rising Iraqi oil sales have combined to force prices down this year.

Independent forecaster Weather Services Corporation predicted "above average temperatures" throughout Europe this week as well as a warmer spell in the United States, cutting into demand for heating oil.
"The direction of heating oil is the direction of the market in the short-term," said Gignoux.
The market will also be watching for the weekly U.S. oil inventory data from the American Petroleum Institute (API) scheduled for release after markets close on Tuesday.
"Few weeks of the winter season remain, while stocks (of heating oil) have been on the rise compared with a year ago," said Leslie Nicholas with brokers GNI Ltd in a daily report.
"Although a draw of around two million barrels is expected, remember that is was cold late last season so the year-to-year excess is likely to widen."

In the week ended February 14, the API said heating oil supplies were about even with a year ago in the energy hungry northeast United States and 1.3 million barrels over year ago levels for the country as a whole.
One effect of this year's price drop is that Iraq will export more oil to meet a target allowed under the United Nations' oil-for-food exchange which began in December.
Iraq can export one billions dollars' worth of oil by March 9, and a futher billion dollars by early June when the deal comes up for review at the United Nations.

With Iraqi crude now fetching about $5 a barrel less than in December, analysts say Baghdad will need to export around 800,000 barrels per day over the next week and a half to meet its cash target -- down from around 500,000 bpd in January.
Crude oil prices in dollars per barrel:
Feb 25 Feb 24
(1636 GMT) (close)
Dated Brent $20.07 $19.87
IPE London Brent futures (Apr) $19.58 $19.12
NYMEX light crude futures (Apr) $21.09 $20.71
LON MME
